Easy Vegetable Stir-Fry

Jump to Recipe

Looking to whip up a quick, nutritious meal that bursts with flavor? This Easy Vegetable Stir-Fry is your answer! Packed with vibrant mixed vegetables like bell peppers, broccoli, and snap peas, this dish is not only delightful to the taste buds but also a feast for the eyes. Whether you’re a busy professional looking for a weeknight dinner solution or a health-conscious foodie wanting to incorporate more veggies into your diet, this stir-fry is ready in just 15 minutes and can easily be customized to suit your taste. With simple ingredients like garlic, ginger, and soy sauce, you’ll create a delicious and satisfying meal that’s perfect served over rice or noodles. Plus, it’s vegan-friendly and loaded with vitamins, making it an ideal choice for everyone. Let’s dive into this easy recipe that proves healthy eating can be quick and delicious!

Ingredients

mixed vegetables (bell peppers, broccoli, carrots, snap peas)

Feel free to use any combination of fresh or frozen vegetables. If using frozen, add them directly to the pan without thawing to maintain their crunch. You can substitute with other vegetables like zucchini, asparagus, or mushrooms based on your preference.

soy sauce

For a gluten-free option, use tamari instead of soy sauce. If you prefer a low-sodium version, opt for low-sodium soy sauce to reduce salt intake. You can also experiment with coconut aminos for a slightly sweeter flavor.

olive oil

While olive oil is great for this dish, you can substitute with vegetable oil or sesame oil for a more authentic Asian flavor. If using sesame oil, consider using it in combination with a neutral oil since it has a strong flavor.

garlic (minced)

Fresh garlic provides the best flavor, but you can use garlic powder as a substitute if necessary (1/8 teaspoon per clove). To enhance the flavor, consider roasting the garlic before adding it to the stir-fry.

ginger (minced)

Fresh ginger adds a zingy flavor, but ground ginger can be used in a pinch (1/4 teaspoon per teaspoon of fresh). For a more intense flavor, grate the ginger instead of mincing it.

sesame seeds (optional)

Toasting sesame seeds before adding them will enhance their nutty flavor. If you don't have sesame seeds, crushed peanuts or cashews can be a great substitute for added crunch.

green onions (sliced)

Both the green and white parts of green onions are edible and flavorful. If you don't have green onions, you can substitute with chives or shallots for a different but complementary flavor.

salt and pepper to taste

Always taste your dish before adding salt, especially since soy sauce is already salty. For added depth, consider using freshly cracked black pepper or a sprinkle of chili flakes for heat.

Cooking Steps

  • Step 1: Heat the Olive Oil

    In a large skillet or wok, heat 2 tablespoons of olive oil over medium-high heat. Allow the oil to heat up for about 1-2 minutes until it's shimmering. This ensures that the vegetables will stir-fry rather than steam.

  • Step 2: Sauté Garlic and Ginger

    Add 2 cloves of minced garlic and 1 teaspoon of minced ginger to the skillet. Sauté for about 30 seconds, stirring continuously, until fragrant. Be careful not to burn the garlic, as it can turn bitter.

  • Step 3: Add Mixed Vegetables

    Add 4 cups of mixed vegetables (bell peppers, broccoli, carrots, snap peas) to the skillet. Stir-fry for about 5-7 minutes. Keep the vegetables moving in the pan to ensure they cook evenly and retain their vibrant colors and crunch.

  • Step 4: Add Soy Sauce

    Pour in 3 tablespoons of soy sauce over the stir-fried vegetables. Stir well to ensure all the vegetables are coated evenly with the sauce. This step adds flavor and enhances the color of the dish.

  • Step 5: Season and Garnish

    Season the stir-fry with salt and pepper to taste. If desired, sprinkle 1 tablespoon of sesame seeds over the top for added texture and flavor. Remove the skillet from heat.

  • Step 6: Serve

    Garnish the stir-fry with sliced green onions (2 green onions) before serving. This adds a fresh crunch and a pop of color. Serve hot, either alone or over a bed of rice or noodles for a complete meal.

Frequently Asked Questions

What types of vegetables work best for stir-fries?

You can use a wide variety of vegetables for stir-fries! Common choices include bell peppers, broccoli, carrots, snap peas, and zucchini. Choose a mix of colors and textures for a more vibrant dish.

How do I prepare vegetables for stir-frying?

Wash your vegetables thoroughly, and then cut them into uniform bite-sized pieces. This ensures even cooking. For example, slice bell peppers into strips, chop broccoli into florets, and slice carrots into thin rounds.

How do I know when my stir-fry is done?

Vegetables should be crisp-tender, meaning they are cooked but still have a bit of crunch. This typically takes about 5-7 minutes over medium-high heat.

Can I use other oils instead of olive oil?

Yes! While olive oil is great, you can also use oils with higher smoke points like vegetable oil, canola oil, or peanut oil for stir-frying.

What if I don't have fresh garlic or ginger?

You can use garlic and ginger powder as substitutes! Use about 1/4 teaspoon of each for every clove or teaspoon of fresh. However, fresh ingredients provide a more vibrant flavor.

How can I make my stir-fry more flavorful?

In addition to soy sauce, consider adding a splash of sesame oil, a pinch of red pepper flakes, or a squeeze of lime juice for extra flavor. Experiment with different seasonings!

What should I do if my vegetables start to burn?

If you notice burning, reduce the heat slightly and add a splash of water or broth to the pan to deglaze it and prevent sticking.

Is it necessary to use sesame seeds?

No, sesame seeds are optional, but they add a nice crunch and nutty flavor. Feel free to skip them or substitute with crushed peanuts or cashews.

How do I safely handle a hot skillet?

Always use oven mitts or pot holders when handling hot cookware. Keep your hands and face away from the edge of the skillet to avoid burns.

Can I prepare my vegetables ahead of time?

Absolutely! You can wash and chop your vegetables a day in advance. Store them in an airtight container in the refrigerator to keep them fresh.

Additional Information

Dietary Considerations

This stir-fry is naturally vegetarian and can easily be made vegan by ensuring that the soy sauce is gluten-free and using a plant-based protein option like tofu. For those watching carbs, serve it over cauliflower rice or enjoy it on its own. If you're looking for a low-sodium option, use low-sodium soy sauce.

Pairings

For a complete meal, pair the Easy Vegetable Stir-Fry with jasmine or brown rice to absorb the flavors. For protein options, consider adding grilled chicken, shrimp, or tofu for a vegetarian option. A light, crisp white wine like Sauvignon Blanc or a refreshing iced green tea complements the dish well.

Serving Suggestions

Serve the stir-fry hot in a large bowl or on individual plates. Garnish with additional sesame seeds and green onions for an appealing presentation. You can also serve it with lime wedges on the side for an added citrus kick. Consider using chopsticks for an authentic Asian dining experience.

Easy Vegetable Stir-Fry

25 min
$10
150 kcal
Difficulty: 20%
Servings: 4

Allergens:

Soy

Dietary Tags:

VegetarianVeganGluten-Free

Cuisine:

AsianAmerican

Course:

MainSide

Tags:

QuickHealthyColorful

Description

A colorful mix of fresh vegetables sautéed to perfection, combined with a light soy sauce for a quick, healthy meal.

Ingredients

  • mixed vegetables (bell peppers, broccoli, carrots, snap peas): 4 cups
  • soy sauce: 3 tablespoons
  • olive oil: 2 tablespoons
  • garlic (minced): 2 cloves
  • ginger (minced): 1 teaspoon
  • sesame seeds (optional): 1 tablespoon
  • green onions (sliced): 2
  • salt and pepper to taste: to taste
